content.description: Practice your mantling skills on this. Start on the arete and topout through the roof.
content.protection: One pad and another to level out the first. Watch the roll.
content.location: If you are in the trail it's hard to miss. About 2/3rds of the way down the switchbacks.

climbs.name: Left Side is the Strong Side

content.description: Start on the left side of the overhang boulder and pop to the top. There may be some tied logs to help even out pad placements.
content.location: After the switch backs look across to an obvious overhanging/roof boulder.

content.description: This crack has all you want, just not enough of it. Fingerlocks give way to hands and finally giving you a fist if you want it. This problem can be as easy or hard as you want it to be.Also a very good downclimb for problems in this area
content.location: The nicer crack right of Fernendipity.

content.description: Climb up the gully and avoid any thoughts of the awkward slide potential if you fell. Juggy holds and pockets await you at the top.
content.protection: Pad for the top and someone to catch you at the bottom?
content.location: Behind the heel hook boulder or furthest right from the fern rock band.

content.description: Start low, detached blocks are off. Utilize crimps, jams, and jugs up to an easy top out. Fall can be a bit rough.
content.location: Left side of the trail as you head downhill. Near a patch of ferns.

content.description: Doing a hanging sit start (or a normal sit start if your arms are long enough). Great crimps and underlings. The lone fern on a sloper really pulls it all together.
content.location: Follow the band of rock around the corner away from the trail.

content.description: Stand start just above the roof lip, pull on and get your feet how you want. Deep pockets with loose rock lead to the top. Watch the mantle because of the slanted rock below.
content.location: Across Cuffs Run on the left side of the overhanging boulder.

content.description: Fun problem with dishes, crimps, and side pulls. Eliminate the arete to up the ante, a little bit.
content.location: Right side of the trail, on the downhill side.

content.description: Sit start with a left hand undercling and your right hand on the arete. Move up the arete and enjoy the topout.
content.protection: Pad, a second one can be used to level out the landing.
content.location: Coming down the trail from the north, this climb will be on your left. About 20 ft from the trail.

content.description: Narrow valley with boulders along a creek or on the side of the hillsides. Time and erosion have made some unique features. That being said, check out the holds before fully committing.Routes are organized from Noth to South as you would encounter them on the trail.Parking can get a bit tight here. Shares a pulloffs with a popular cliff jumping spot.
